Stem: An ermine weasel changes its fur color from brown to white in winter. Evaluate the following statements about how this helps the weasel survive: (True/False for 5 statements about camouflage, predator avoidance, and seasonal adaptation).
Choices: True/False for 5 statements about ermine weasel survival traits
Scenario Justification: Real organism scenario involving seasonal adaptation. Students must evaluate multiple statements about how fur color change helps survival. Requires reasoning about behavioral and structural adaptations.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate multiple claims about adaptation and survival. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence — must assess each statement's validity against understanding of camouflage and predator-prey relationships.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that organisms have structures and behaviors that help them survive in their environments. Applied across multiple statements requiring nuanced judgment.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect — fur color change (cause) improves survival (effect) — but the CCC is not explicitly required as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Good multi-statement format that tests nuanced understanding. Could elevate by asking students to explain WHY white fur helps in winter specifically, engaging Structure and Function more explicitly.

Stem: Compare Waves A and B shown in the figure. Which statement correctly identifies a difference between the two waves?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing two waves (Wave A and Wave B) with different amplitudes and/or wavelengths
Choices: A) Wave A has a longer wavelength than Wave B, B) Wave B has a larger amplitude than Wave A, C) Wave A has a larger amplitude than Wave B, D) Both waves have the same amplitude and wavelength
Scenario Justification: Visual comparison of two wave diagrams. Students must analyze wave properties from diagrams and identify specific differences in amplitude or wavelength.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret data from wave models. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data — must compare visual representations to identify measurable differences.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding wave properties (amplitude, wavelength) and the ability to distinguish them visually. Applied understanding beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns — recognizing differences in wave shape as meaningful property differences — but CCC is not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Solid visual analysis question. Strengthen by adding a Part B asking students to predict which wave carries more energy and explain why, connecting amplitude to energy transfer.

Stem: Melissa and Rebecca created models of two waves. Which statement best describes the relationship between the two waves in the models?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing two waves with different wavelengths but same amplitude
Choices: A) The amplitudes are the same regardless of wavelength, B) The wave with the longer wavelength has a higher amplitude, C) The wave with the shorter wavelength has a higher amplitude, D) Wavelength and amplitude are always equal
Scenario Justification: Students compare two wave models and must reason about the independence of amplitude and wavelength. Requires genuine analysis of wave properties rather than simple recall.
SEP Justification: Students analyze wave models to determine the relationship between two properties. Engages Developing and Using Models and Analyzing and Interpreting Data.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that amplitude and wavelength are independent properties of waves. Goes beyond recall to understanding property relationships.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — recognizing that amplitude remains constant while wavelength varies. Students identify a meaningful pattern in wave behavior.
Key Recommendation: Good conceptual question about wave property independence. Could elevate by asking students to draw a third wave with a different wavelength but the same amplitude, engaging model construction.

Stem: Hawks have entered a forest ecosystem with an existing food web. The food web shows that foxes and hawks both eat mice. Select all that apply: What changes might happen in this food web?
Choices: A) Mice increase, B) Plants decrease, C) Mice decrease, D) Foxes may decrease due to competition, E) Hawks will leave
Scenario Justification: Scenario involves a food web disruption but food webs and ecosystem interactions are not part of Grade 4 NGSS standards (this is Grade 5 content: 5-LS2-1). The scenario requires reasoning about predator-prey dynamics.
SEP Justification: Students predict outcomes from a food web change. Engages Constructing Explanations but the reasoning is limited to basic predator-prey logic.
DCI Justification: Food webs and ecosystem interactions are Grade 5 DCI (LS2.A). Not aligned to Grade 4 standards. Content is below the complexity expected for the standard it would align to.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — new predator (cause) leads to prey decline and competition effects (effect). Basic causal reasoning.
Key Recommendation: OFF-GRADE CONTENT: Food webs are Grade 5 NGSS (5-LS2-1). Remove or replace with a Grade 4 aligned question about organism structures/behaviors for survival (4-LS1).

Stem: Sonya sets up a terrarium to show matter cycling in an ecosystem. Select all that would help demonstrate matter cycling in her terrarium.
Choices: A) Add worms and fungi as decomposers, B) Add more plants only, C) Add a lizard whose droppings return nutrients to soil, D) Seal the terrarium completely, E) Remove all soil
Scenario Justification: Scenario involves matter cycling in ecosystems which is a Grade 5 concept (5-LS2-1). Students must reason about decomposition and nutrient cycling. The terrarium context is engaging but misaligned to Grade 4 standards.
SEP Justification: Students select components that demonstrate matter cycling. Engages Planning and Carrying Out Investigations at a basic level — choosing design elements for a system.
DCI Justification: Matter cycling in ecosystems is Grade 5 DCI (LS2.B). Not aligned to Grade 4 NGSS standards. The concept requires understanding of decomposition and nutrient cycles.
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models — terrarium as a model ecosystem — but the system-level reasoning is implicit.
Key Recommendation: OFF-GRADE CONTENT: Matter cycling in ecosystems is Grade 5 NGSS (5-LS2-1). Replace with Grade 4 content about internal/external structures that support survival (4-LS1-1).

Stem: In an ecosystem, energy flows from one organism to another. Which statement best describes how energy flows in an ecosystem?
Choices: A) Energy flows from animals to the sun, B) Grass uses and stores energy from the sun and this energy flows to all other organisms, C) Energy is created by consumers, D) Energy flows from predators to prey
Scenario Justification: Basic question about ecosystem energy flow. Energy flow through ecosystems is Grade 5 content. The question itself is fairly recall-oriented with no specific scenario.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engaged. Students select a factual statement about energy flow. Pure recall.
DCI Justification: Energy flow through ecosystems is Grade 5 DCI. Not aligned to Grade 4 NGSS. The content is basic recall even for Grade 5.
CCC Justification: No CCC explicitly engaged beyond the implicit concept of Energy and Matter flow.
Key Recommendation: OFF-GRADE CONTENT: Ecosystem energy flow is Grade 5 NGSS (5-PS3-1, 5-LS2-1). Replace with Grade 4 energy transfer/conversion content (4-PS3-2).

Stem: When light bounces off an object, the light is said to be ___.
Choices: A) reflected, B) refracted, C) absorbed, D) transmitted
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure vocabulary recall about light behavior. The question tests only a definition.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of a vocabulary term.
DCI Justification: Tests recall of the definition of reflection. No application or reasoning required. Pure terminology.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary recall. Redesign with a scenario: show a student looking at an object and ask why they can see it, requiring students to apply the concept of reflection to explain vision.

Stem: A concave lens causes objects to appear smaller. Which of the following is NOT likely to use a concave lens?
Choices: A) Magnifying glass, B) Peephole in a door, C) Security camera, D) Rearview mirror on a car
Scenario Justification: Provides some context about lens properties but the question is essentially classification/recall about which devices use which lens types. The NOT format adds a layer of reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students must apply knowledge of concave vs. convex lens applications. Engages basic reasoning about Structure and Function of optical devices but is primarily recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of concave lens properties and their applications. Applied at classification level. Lens types are related to 4-PS4-2 but the specific lens type content may exceed Grade 4 expectations.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function — lens shape determines its optical effect — but the CCC is not the focus of reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Primarily recall of lens applications. The NOT format can confuse students without adding depth. Redesign by providing a scenario where students must select the correct lens for a specific purpose and explain why.

Stem: In a parallel circuit with three lightbulbs, what happens if one lightbulb goes out?
Choices: A) All lightbulbs go out, B) The remaining lightbulbs get brighter, C) All lightbulbs except the broken one stay lit, D) The circuit stops working completely
Scenario Justification: Basic question about parallel circuit behavior. No investigation or data context — students simply recall how parallel circuits function.
SEP Justification: Students apply understanding of parallel circuits to predict an outcome. Limited practice depth — straightforward application of a rule.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that parallel circuits maintain independent paths so one failure does not affect others. Applied at a basic level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect — one bulb failing (cause) does not affect others (effect) — but reasoning is minimal.
Key Recommendation: Basic recall of parallel circuit behavior. Redesign by providing both series and parallel circuit diagrams with data, asking students to compare outcomes and explain WHY they differ using energy flow reasoning.

Stem: A solar energy system is shown in Figure 2. Part A: Which piece of evidence from the figure shows that energy is transferred by light?
Image/Diagram Description: Figure 2 showing a solar energy system with panels and heated liquid
Choices: A) The solar panel is dark colored, B) The wires connect to a battery, C) The system is outdoors, D) Energy from the Sun heats the liquid in the system
Scenario Justification: Multi-part question using a diagram of a solar energy system. Students must identify specific evidence of light energy transfer from a figure. Requires analysis of a real system.
SEP Justification: Students analyze evidence from a diagram to identify energy transfer. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data — must connect visual evidence to a scientific claim about energy transfer.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that light carries energy and can be transferred to heat a substance. Applied to a real-world solar energy system.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — tracing energy transfer from light to heat. Students must reason about energy flow through the system.
Key Recommendation: Good evidence-identification question. The two-part structure adds depth. Could be strengthened by asking students to explain how they know the evidence specifically shows light energy rather than another form.

Stem: Part B: Which energy conversion is occurring in the process described in Part A?
Choices: A) Heat to light, B) Light to heat, C) Sound to light, D) Electrical to heat
Scenario Justification: Builds on Part A by asking students to identify the specific energy conversion. The two-part structure requires connected reasoning — first identify evidence, then classify the conversion.
SEP Justification: Students identify an energy conversion from evidence analyzed in Part A. Engages Constructing Explanations — must connect evidence to the correct energy transformation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding energy conversion types and applying them to the specific solar heating system. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Energy and Matter — identifying how energy changes form. Students trace the conversion from light to heat.
Key Recommendation: Good two-part structure that builds connected reasoning. Part B alone is relatively simple; its strength comes from the connection to Part A. Could add a Part C asking about the usefulness of this conversion.

Stem: An oak tree would be placed at which level in an energy pyramid?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram of an energy pyramid with labeled levels
Choices: A) Level 1 (producers/bottom), B) Level 2 (primary consumers), C) Level 3 (secondary consumers), D) Level 4 (top predators)
Scenario Justification: Energy pyramids and trophic levels are Grade 5 content (5-LS2-1). The question is simple classification with an energy pyramid diagram.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Pure recall of where producers fall in an energy pyramid. Direct classification.
DCI Justification: Energy pyramids and trophic levels are Grade 5 DCI (LS2.B). Not aligned to Grade 4 NGSS. Even for Grade 5, this is recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: OFF-GRADE CONTENT: Energy pyramids are Grade 5 NGSS (5-LS2-1). Replace with Grade 4 content about energy transfer or conversion (4-PS3-2).

Stem: What is the hydrosphere?
Choices: A) All of the water inside, on, and around Earth, B) All of the air around Earth, C) All of the rock layers of Earth, D) All of the living organisms on Earth
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure vocabulary recall testing the definition of hydrosphere. No reasoning or application required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of a definition.
DCI Justification: Tests recall of the term hydrosphere. No understanding of Earth systems processes is required. Pure terminology.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary recall. Redesign by presenting data about water distribution on Earth and asking students to explain how water moves between different parts of the hydrosphere, engaging Systems and System Models.

Stem: The diagram shows the distribution of water on planet Earth. Where is the majority of water on Earth found?
Image/Diagram Description: Pie chart or diagram showing distribution of Earth's water
Choices: A) In glaciers, B) In underground aquifers, C) In freshwater lakes, D) In oceans
Scenario Justification: Uses a diagram showing water distribution. Students must read the diagram to identify the largest water reservoir. Minimal reasoning beyond data reading.
SEP Justification: Students read and interpret a data display. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic level — identifying the largest category from a chart.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of Earth's water distribution — most water is in oceans. Applied at data-reading level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Scale, Proportion, and Quantity — comparing relative amounts — but the reasoning is basic chart reading.
Key Recommendation: Basic data reading from a chart. Strengthen by asking students to explain WHY so much of Earth's water is salty and what implications this has for freshwater availability, connecting to 4-ESS3-1.

Stem: Sophia shouts down a deep well and hears an echo a few seconds later. What causes the echo?
Choices: A) The sound is amplified by the well walls, B) The sound reflects off the surface at the bottom of the well, C) The sound is absorbed by the water, D) The sound creates new sound waves underground
Scenario Justification: Real observable phenomenon (echo in a well). Students must apply understanding of sound wave reflection to explain an everyday experience.
SEP Justification: Students select an explanation for an observed phenomenon. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level — the correct answer is fairly transparent.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sound waves reflect off surfaces. Applied to a real phenomenon rather than pure recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — sound hitting a surface (cause) reflects back as echo (effect). Basic causal reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Good phenomenon-based question. Strengthen by adding a follow-up asking students to predict how the echo would change if the well were deeper, and explain their reasoning using wave travel time.

Stem: In a food web, a snake eats mice and is eaten by hawks. Select all that correctly describe the snake's role.
Choices: A) Predator, B) Consumer, C) Prey, D) Producer, E) Decomposer, F) Autotroph, G) Carnivore
Scenario Justification: Food web classification question. Food webs and ecological roles are Grade 5 content (5-LS2-1). The question requires classification of an organism's multiple roles.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engaged. Students classify an organism using ecological vocabulary. Pure recall of definitions.
DCI Justification: Food webs and ecological roles are Grade 5 DCI (LS2.A/LS2.B). Not aligned to Grade 4 NGSS. Even for Grade 5, this is vocabulary recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: OFF-GRADE CONTENT: Food web roles and classification are Grade 5 NGSS (5-LS2-1). Replace with Grade 4 content about organism structures and survival (4-LS1).

Stem: Meteorology is the ___.
Choices: A) Study of rocks and minerals, B) Study of living organisms, C) Study of outer space, D) Scientific study of the atmosphere, weather, and weather forecasting
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure vocabulary recall of the definition of meteorology. Weather and climate are Grade 3 NGSS content (3-ESS2-1). Completely misaligned to Grade 4.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of a vocabulary definition.
DCI Justification: Meteorology/weather is Grade 3 DCI (ESS2.D). Not aligned to Grade 4 NGSS. Pure terminology question.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: OFF-GRADE CONTENT: Weather and meteorology are Grade 3 NGSS (3-ESS2-1). Additionally, this is pure vocabulary recall. Remove entirely and replace with on-grade, phenomenon-based content.

Stem: Which of the following animals is preparing for a seasonal change in its environment?
Choices: A) A bird building a nest in spring, B) A fish swimming upstream, C) A dog chasing a ball, D) A squirrel storing nuts for winter
Scenario Justification: Students must identify which animal behavior represents preparation for seasonal change. Minimal reasoning required — the answer is fairly obvious.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engaged. Students select the correct example of seasonal preparation. Pure identification.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that some animals prepare for seasonal changes through behavior. Basic recall-level application of 4-LS1-2.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Too straightforward. Redesign by presenting data about multiple animal behaviors across seasons and asking students to identify patterns in seasonal preparation behaviors and explain WHY these behaviors help survival.

Stem: Which of the following is a physical adaptation?
Choices: A) A fox's fur turning white in winter, B) A bird migrating south, C) A bear hibernating, D) A dog learning tricks
Scenario Justification: Students must distinguish physical (structural) adaptations from behavioral ones. Minimal scenario but requires classification reasoning.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged beyond classification. Students identify which option is a structural vs. behavioral adaptation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of the distinction between physical and behavioral adaptations. Basic classification applied to examples.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Simple classification. Redesign by presenting an organism in a specific habitat and asking students to explain HOW a physical adaptation helps it survive, engaging Structure and Function.

Stem: How might a plant defend itself from predators? Select all that apply.
Choices: A) Poison, B) Spines, C) Bright flowers, D) Thorns, E) Sweet fruit
Scenario Justification: Students identify plant defense structures. Minimal scenario — the question is essentially classification of plant defense mechanisms.
SEP Justification: Students classify plant features as defensive or non-defensive. Engages basic reasoning about Structure and Function but is primarily recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that plants have structures that protect them from being eaten. Applied at classification level for 4-LS1-1.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function — defense structures serve a protective function — but the CCC is not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Basic classification. Redesign by presenting a specific plant with multiple structures and asking students to explain how EACH structure functions as a defense mechanism, making Structure and Function explicit.

Stem: Why are fossil fuels considered nonrenewable resources?
Choices: A) They are too expensive to extract, B) There is a chance of running out before nature can make more, C) They are found everywhere on Earth, D) They can be recycled easily
Scenario Justification: Basic question about nonrenewable resources. No scenario or data — students must recall why fossil fuels are classified as nonrenewable.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of the definition and reasoning behind nonrenewable classification.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that fossil fuels form over geological time and can be depleted faster than replaced. Basic application of 4-ESS3-1.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Redesign by providing data on fossil fuel consumption rates vs. formation rates and asking students to analyze the data to construct an argument for why these resources are considered nonrenewable.

Stem: Which of the following objects are good conductors of electricity? Select all that apply.
Choices: A) Rubber band, B) Metal fork, C) Wooden stick, D) Aluminum foil, E) Plastic straw
Scenario Justification: Students classify materials as conductors or insulators. No scenario or investigation context — pure classification.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engaged. Students classify materials based on recall of which conduct electricity.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that metals conduct electricity while rubber, wood, and plastic do not. Basic recall/classification for 4-PS3-4.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure classification recall. Redesign by providing data from an investigation where students tested different materials in a circuit and recorded results, asking them to analyze the data and identify the pattern.

Stem: Part A: The graph in Figure 1 shows three objects moving at different speeds over time. Which line represents an object moving at a constant speed?
Image/Diagram Description: Graph (Figure 1) showing speed vs. time with multiple lines
Choices: A) Red line, B) Black line, C) Blue line, D) Green line
Scenario Justification: Multi-part question using a speed-time graph. Students must interpret graphical data to identify constant speed (a flat/horizontal line). Requires data analysis skills.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret graphical data. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data — must read and interpret a speed vs. time graph to identify a pattern (constant speed = horizontal line).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the relationship between speed and time and how constant speed appears on a graph. Applied understanding beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — recognizing that a constant speed produces a specific pattern (horizontal line) on a graph. Students use pattern recognition for interpretation.
Key Recommendation: Good graph interpretation question. The two-part structure builds connected reasoning. Could strengthen by asking students to explain WHAT the other lines represent and what is happening to those objects' speeds.

Stem: Part B: The graph in Figure 2 shows three objects. Which line represents the object moving at the fastest speed?
Image/Diagram Description: Graph (Figure 2) showing speed or distance vs. time with multiple lines
Choices: A) Line A, B) Line B, C) Line C, D) All lines show the same speed
Scenario Justification: Continuation of graph analysis from Part A using a different graph. Students must compare speeds from graphical data to identify the fastest object.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and compare data from a graph. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data — must compare multiple data lines to determine which represents the fastest speed.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how to read speed from a graph and compare multiple objects. Applied understanding building on Part A.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns — comparing line slopes or values — but the reasoning is straightforward graph reading.
Key Recommendation: Solid graph-reading question. Together with Part A, this provides good data analysis practice. Could elevate by asking students to predict what happens when the fastest object encounters friction.

Stem: A solar energy system is shown in Figure 1. Which energy conversion occurs in Step 1 of the system?
Image/Diagram Description: Figure 1 showing a multi-step solar energy system
Choices: A) Heat to light, B) Light to heat, C) Electrical to sound, D) Solar (light) to electrical
Scenario Justification: Students analyze a diagram of a solar energy system to identify a specific energy conversion at a specific step. Requires reading and interpreting a technical diagram.
SEP Justification: Students analyze a diagram to identify an energy conversion at a specific step. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data from a technical figure.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of solar energy conversion — photovoltaic panels convert light energy to electrical energy. Applied to a specific system step.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — tracing energy conversion through a system. Students reason about how energy changes form at each step.
Key Recommendation: Good diagram-based question. Strengthen by asking students to trace the complete energy conversion chain through all steps and explain what happens to the energy at each stage.

Stem: A student holds a cold bowl of ice cream. True or false: Heat transfers from the cold bowl to the student's warm hands.
Choices: A) True, B) False
Scenario Justification: Targets a common misconception about heat transfer direction. Students must reason that heat flows from warm to cold (hands to bowl), not cold to warm. Good misconception-probing question.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate a scientific claim about heat transfer direction. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence — must apply understanding to reject an incorrect claim.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that heat always transfers from warmer to cooler objects. This directly addresses a persistent misconception. Application-level for 4-PS3-2.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — temperature difference (cause) drives heat transfer in a specific direction (effect). Also Energy and Matter — energy flows from warm to cold.
Key Recommendation: Excellent misconception-targeting question. The true/false format limits depth, however. Strengthen by asking students to explain the direction of heat transfer and what happens to the ice cream and hands over time.

Stem: Volcanoes are found along the Ring of Fire in the Pacific Ocean. Why are there so many volcanoes concentrated in this region?
Choices: A) The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean, B) This region has many tectonic plate boundaries, C) The water in the Pacific is warmer, D) Volcanic rock only forms near oceans
Scenario Justification: Real-world geographic phenomenon (Ring of Fire). Students must connect volcanic activity to plate tectonics. Requires application of Earth science knowledge to explain a pattern.
SEP Justification: Students select a causal explanation for a geographic pattern. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level — the correct answer is fairly recognizable.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the connection between plate boundaries and volcanic/earthquake activity. Applied understanding of Earth processes for 4-ESS2-2.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — explaining why volcanoes cluster in a ring pattern around the Pacific. Also Cause and Effect — plate boundaries (cause) create volcanic activity (effect).
Key Recommendation: Good real-world phenomenon. Strengthen by providing a map with both earthquake and volcano data and asking students to identify the pattern and explain why both hazards cluster at plate boundaries.

Stem: Students observe trees on a hillside with bent trunks. The trees appear to be leaning downhill and soil has moved from around their roots. What most likely caused the soil to move on this hillside?
Image/Diagram Description: Image showing trees with bent trunks on a hillside
Choices: A) Animals dug up the soil, B) Gravity and erosion slowly moved soil downhill, C) The trees pushed the soil away, D) Wind blew the soil to a different location
Scenario Justification: Real observable phenomenon with visual evidence (bent trees, exposed roots). Students must reason about what force or process caused the observed changes to the hillside over time.
SEP Justification: Students analyze observational evidence to construct a causal explanation. Engages Constructing Explanations from Evidence — must connect bent trees and moved soil to an erosion process.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding Earth surface processes — gravity-driven erosion (creep) moves soil downhill over time. Applied to a real field observation.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — gravity and erosion (cause) move soil downhill over time (effect), resulting in bent trees. Also Stability and Change — slow change over time.
Key Recommendation: Strong observational reasoning question. Could elevate by asking students to predict what will happen to the hillside over the next 50 years and what evidence they would look for to support their prediction.

Stem: [Image-based multi-part question Part A] Students analyze a figure and answer a question about an Earth science or physical science concept based on visual evidence.
Choices: A) B) C) D)
Scenario Justification: Multi-part question with image-based content. Without the full text and image, a complete evaluation is limited. Scored conservatively based on typical multi-part MC format.
SEP Justification: Without full stem text, practice engagement cannot be fully evaluated. Scored conservatively assuming basic analysis of a figure.
DCI Justification: Without full content, DCI alignment and depth cannot be fully evaluated. Scored conservatively.
CCC Justification: Without full content, CCC engagement cannot be fully evaluated. Scored conservatively.
Key Recommendation: INCOMPLETE EXTRACTION: Full question text and image were not captured during test extraction. Re-scan this question to enable complete evaluation.
